bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, July 12, 1922

div1.p: Rose reports that the western coast of South American is free from yellow fever. There are still cases of yellow fever in eastern Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, July 12, 1922

HIDEYO NOGUCHI, M.D.
JOSEPH H. WHITE, M.D.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
There has been no yellow fever in Peru since
July one year ago. The country has been officially de-
clared free from infection and the work has been closed.
This would seem to finish the work for the west coast of
South America. Reports from the field indicate that
there is no yellow fever infection anywhere in this re-
gion.

For the entire territory of Mexico and Central
America only one case of yellow fever has been reported
since January. Doctor White thinks this case was not
yellow fever. Doctor White and Doctor Connor are now
making a survey of this entire field. Doctor White is
sending in reports from time to time as the survey pro-
ceeds. So far as we know there is no present focus of
infection in this entire region. We are not prepared as
yet to say that there is none but the situation looks ex-
Doctor H R Carter
July 12, 1922
2
tremely encouraging. If no fever is found anywhere in
this region between this time and the end of the year
the region will be declared free of infection and the
work will be closed at that time. It is already being
closed out in definite areas that are clearly free.

At the present time we have knowledge of no
infection anywhere on the Western Hemisphere outside
the region in eastern Brazil from Pernambuco to Bahia.

These facts we are sending to each member of
the yellow fever council and should like to have advice
on the following: If up to the end of the year no
yellow fever has been reported from any region except
the one in Brazil to which reference is made, should
we rely upon the fact that no case has been reported
from the region along the Caribbean littoral and up the
Amazon valley, for the last two or three years; or,
should we write to the health authorities in these various
countries to have specific reports from them, and rely
upon the fact that no fever has been reported, reinforced
by this official report from the several countries; or
would it be advisable for the International Health Board
to send someone to make a thorough survey of the Carib-
Doctor H R Carter
July 12, 1922
3
bean littoral and the Amazon Valley?

We should greatly appreciate your counsel
in the matter.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Doctor H R Carter
